Cherokee Nitrogen, LLC Executive Summary



1.0    Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies

We at Cherokee Nitrogen are strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at out facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.



2.0    Cherokee Nitrogen, LLC and Regulated Substances

Our facility's primary activities encompass the manufacture of ammonia and related processes.  Ammonia is a natural part of the life process.  It is produced internally by all humans and mammals to process essential proteins.  Ammonia is one of the most widely used industrial chemicals in the world, and is commonly used to purify water and refrigerate foods.



The company is a supplier to the fertilizer, explosives, and commercial industries by manufacturing ammonium nitrate, ammonium nitrate solutions, and other products.   Cherokee Nitrogen markets its fertilizers to distributors, dealers, national farm retail chains, regional farm cooperatives, and other fertilizer producers for ultimate sale and delivery to farmers.



We have four regulated substances present at our facility at or above threshold quantities.  These substances include ammonia (anhydrous), ammonia (conc. 20% or greater), chlorine, and sulfur dioxide.  Anhydrous ammonia is used to manufacture nitric acid (<80 percent).  Aqueous ammonia is contained within the letdown, urea, and ammonium nitrate solutions processes.  Chlorine is used to treat the incoming process water prior to use by the facility.  Sulfur dioxide is used to treat the outgoing process water prior to discharge from the facility.



Typically, the facility manufactures two types of ammonium nitrate solutions:  industrial grade (83 weight perce

nt) ammonium nitrate solution and a high pressure solution consisting of 24 to 25 percent ammonia and 69 to 70 percent ammonium nitrate.  The industrial grade ammonium nitrate is used as a primary building block for commercial explosives and blasting agents.  Without this product, the mining of precious metals and gems, coal for power, and concrete for construction would be much less safe and much more expensive. 



As this RMP will illustrate, our accidental release prevention programs and our emergency response planning efforts help us effectively manage any potential hazards posed by these regulated substances.



3.0    Accidental Release Prevention Program

Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with ASME codes.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our stationary source.



3.1    Process Safety Information

Cherokee Nitrogen maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with all processes.



3.2    Process Hazard Analysis

Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analysis is HAZOP.  The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are re-validated at a regular interval of every five years.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.  The most recent PHA/update was performed on April 9, 2014.

    

3.3    Operating Procedures

For the purpose of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, Cherokee Nitrogen maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of op

eration such as initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and start-up after turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process.



3.4    Training

Cherokee Nitrogen has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.



3.5    Mechanical Integrity

Cherokee Nitrogen carries out highly documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others:  pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.

    

Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



3.6    Management of Change 

Written procedures are in place at Cherokee Nitrogen to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures.  The most recent review/revision of Management of Change procedures was performed on June 18, 2014.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.



3.7    Pre-startup Reviews

Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at Cherokee Nitrogen.  The most recent review was performed on August 19, 2014.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, and operating and m

aintenance procedures are suitable for safe start-up prior to placing equipment into operation.



3.8    Compliance Audits

Cherokee Nitrogen conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set forth under the RMP rule are being implemented.  The most recent compliance audit was conducted on June 27, 2014.  These audits are carried out at least every 3 years, and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.



3.9    Incident Investigation

Cherokee Nitrogen promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are under taken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of five years.



3.10    Employee Participation

Cherokee Nitrogen truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analysis, in particular.



3.11    Contractors

On occasion, our company hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  Cherokee Nitrogen has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards to related the contractor's work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should accidental release of a regulated substance occur.



4.0    Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



4.1    Anhydrous Ammonia

Several process controls are in place to pre

vent and/or mitigate accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  These controls include vents, relief valves, check valves, manual and automatic shut-offs, interlocks, alarms, emergency back-up power, back-up pumps, ruptured disks, excess flow devices, and water cannons.



4.2    Ammonia Solutions (>20%)

Several process controls are, likewise, in place to prevent and/or mitigate accidental releases of ammonia solutions.  These controls include vents, relief valves, check valves, manual and automatic shut-offs, interlocks, alarms, back-up pumps, and excess flow devices.



4.2    Chlorine

Several process controls are, likewise, in place to prevent and/or mitigate accidental releases of chlorine.  These controls include relief valves, manual shut-offs, alarms and procedures, and monitoring systems.



4.2    Sulfur Dioxide

Several process controls are, likewise, in place to prevent and/or mitigate accidental releases of sulfur dioxide.  These controls include relief valves, manual shut-offs, alarms and procedures, and monitoring systems.



5.0    Five Year Accident History 

Cherokee Nitrogen has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  Due to our stringent release prevention policies, there have been no accidental releases of regulated substances from RMP covered processes within our facility during the last five years that resulted in on-site or off-site consequences, including deaths, injuries, significant property damage, environmental damage, off-site evacuation, or sheltering in place.

    

The following is a brief summary substantiating the accident history involving materials covered under EPSA's RMP Rule during the previous five years.



5.1    Anhydrous Ammonia

During the past five years, Cherokee Nitrogen has not had an accidental anhydrous ammonia release resulting in on-site or off-site consequences, including deaths, injuries, significant property damage, environmental damage, off-site evacuation, or sheltering in place.

5.2    Ammonia Solutions (>20%)

During the past five years, Cherokee Nitrogen has not had an accidental ammonia solutions release resulting in on-site or off-site consequences, including deaths, injuries, significant property damage, environmental damage, off-site evacuation, or sheltering in place.



5.3    Chlorine

During the past five years, Cherokee Nitrogen has not had an accidental chlorine release resulting in on-site or off-site consequences, including deaths, injuries, significant property damage, environmental damage, off-site evacuation, or sheltering in place.



5.4    Sulfur Dioxide

During the past five years, Cherokee Nitrogen has not had an accidental sulfur dioxide release resulting in on-site or off-site consequences, including deaths, injuries, significant property damage, environmental damage, off-site evacuation, or sheltering in place.



6.0    Emergency Response Programs

Cherokee Nitrogen maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response.



Colbert County LEPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which our emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.



7.0    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Cherokee Nitrogen continually strives to improve and upgrade operating procedures, replace or maintain equipment, and develop and implement safety improvement projects.  Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release pre

vention program.  Some of the major steps taken to improve safety at our facility include:  installation of security/safety cables on all overhead chain operated valves, a continuation of CPR and AED training, semi-annual third party safety inspections and audits with corrective action and follow up, quarterly internal safety inspections with corrective action and follow up, establishment of a safety steering committee, establishing safety goals, plant wide monthly safety awareness meetings which focus on safety needs and input from all employees, and increases in site security measures.

    

These activities are implemented and reflect current practices established at Cherokee Nitrogen.
